source: Little is beyond their reach. Official documents and private communications are made public, and websites blocked. They hijack CCTV cameras, electronic billboards and network printers. The best known of the virtual warriors are the Ukrainian Cyber Troops, the Cyber Berkut and Anonymous International. All three present themselves as independent activists, separate from other, government-sponsored groups. The most prominent pro-Ukrainians hackers are the Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Kiev-based programmer Yevhen Dokukin. Most recently, he claimed to have hacked into two Russian interior ministry servers and an email account used by police in Russia's Rostov region - bordering Ukraine's eastern separatist regions. "I gave all this data to Ukraine's security service, but they still can't get round to analysing it, so do it yourselves," he urged readers on Facebook. Volunteer activist group Inform Napalm sifted through more than 35 gigabytes of the data and found what looked like official reports confirming that Russian military servicemen were among the hundreds of people evacuated to Russia after being wounded in Ukraine. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops make extensive use of one of the most tried and tested tools in cyber warfare, the distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attack. "DDoS attacks are the Ukrainian Cyber Troops' artillery," Mr Dokukin likes saying. Scores of rebel websites were made inaccessible when the Ukrainian Cyber Troops relentlessly bombarded them with fake service requests. To disrupt separatist funding, they target accounts held by rebels in electronic payment systems such as PayPal and WebMoney. The Cyber Troops have also hacked into public CCTV systems in rebel-held areas of eastern Ukraine and monitor them for the movement of troops and military hardware. On 8 December, Yevhen Dokukin claimed to have hijacked network printers in eastern Ukraine and Crimea to print pro-Ukrainian messages and insults against Russian President Vladimir Putin. Some media reports suggest that Ukraine's security services have used information obtained by hackers to direct artillery fire. But officials deny this. "We only use data obtained by people we trust and know," Ukrainian military spokesman Oleksiy Dmytrashkivsky told the BBC. On the other side of the conflict is Cyber Berkut, a staunchly anti-Western group which takes its name from the riot police used against protesters during the unrest in Kiev that led to the ousting of President Viktor Yanukovych. The group's declared goal is thwarting Ukraine's military plans and thus stopping the "genocide" that it accuses Kiev of unleashing at America's behest. Its motto is "We won't forgive or forget", and its rhetoric closely resembles that of Russian state media. During US Vice-President Joe Biden's visit to Kiev on 20-21 November, Cyber Berkut hacked several Ukrainian government websites, placing a message on their front pages which read: "Joseph Biden is the fascists' master." Cyber Berkut claims to have retrieved confidential documents from a mobile device used by one member of Mr Biden's team while it was in Kiev. The documents appear to detail Washington's military assistance to Ukraine. Another stunt carried out by Cyber Berkut is the apparent hacking of electronic billboards in Kiev, which were made to show a video branding Ukrainian officials and activists "war criminals" and featuring highly graphic images of civilians killed in the current conflict. They also claim to have disrupted the electronic vote-counting systems ahead of October's parliamentary election in Ukraine, to have leaked Ukrainian defence ministry data on losses and desertions, and to have blocked President Petro Poroshenko's website. In addition, Russian tabloid Komsomolskaya Pravda quoted a Facebook conversation allegedly hacked by Cyber Berkut, in which Ukrainian officials appear to admit that their forces downed Malaysia Airlines flight MH17. The claim went largely ignored elsewhere and has never been verified. Russian activist group Anonymous International made its name by publishing leaked documents from the Kremlin. It is otherwise known as b0ltai or Shaltay Boltay, which translates as "Humpty Dumpty". What is not clear is whether it obtains material through hacking or are given it by Kremlin insiders. The group focuses on Russia's domestic affairs, but some of its material covers Ukraine. In  November it published a letter from a Russian fighter in eastern Ukraine suggesting that locals did not support the separatist forces. And in May it made headlines leaking what it said were emails to and from former Russian FSB colonel Igor Girkin, also known as Strelkov, who was then a key rebel commander in eastern Ukraine. Access to Anonymous International's website is currently blocked in Russia. BBC Monitoring reports and analyses news from TV, radio, web and print media around the world. For more reports from BBC Monitoring, click here. You can follow BBC Monitoring on Twitter and Facebook.
summary:
The passage discusses cyber activities in the ongoing conflict between Ukraine and Russia. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, are highlighted as a group that uses DDoS attacks to make rebel websites inaccessible, targets accounts held by rebels in electronic payment systems, hacks into public CCTV systems, and hijacks network printers to print pro-Ukrainian messages. Inform Napalm, a volunteer activist group, has sifted through data obtained by the Ukrainian Cyber Troops and found evidence of Russian military involvement in Ukraine.

On the other side, Cyber Berkut, an anti-Western group, is known for hacking Ukrainian government websites, disrupting electronic vote-counting systems, leaking Ukrainian defence ministry data, and blocking President Petro Poroshenko's website. They have also been accused of hacking a device used by a member of Joe Biden's team during his visit to Kiev, allegedly obtaining documents detailing Washington's military assistance to Ukraine.

Russian activist group Anonymous International, also known as b0ltai or Shaltay B

summary: The passage discusses the activities of three groups involved in cyber warfare: Ukrainian Cyber Troops, Cyber Berkut, and Anonymous International. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, are known for their extensive use of distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks, hacking into Russian servers, and monitoring CCTV systems in rebel-held areas. They have also targeted electronic payment systems and hacked network printers to print pro-Ukrainian messages. Cyber Berkut, an anti-Western group, aims to thwart Ukraine's military plans and has hacked Ukrainian government websites, electronic billboards, and disrupted electronic vote-counting systems. Anonymous International, a Russian activist group, focuses on Russia's domestic affairs and has published leaked documents related to Ukraine. The passage also mentions that Ukraine's security services have denied using hacked information to direct artillery fire.

summary:
Here's a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information:

The passage describes three main hacking groups involved in the Ukraine-Russia conflict:

1. Ukrainian Cyber Troops: Led by Yevhen Dokukin, they hack Russian servers, conduct DDoS attacks on rebel websites, disrupt separatist funding, and monitor CCTV systems in rebel-held areas. They claim to provide information to Ukrainian security services.

2. Cyber Berkut: A pro-Russian group that targets Ukrainian government websites, leaks confidential documents, and spreads anti-Western propaganda. They've hacked electronic billboards and claim to have disrupted Ukraine's electronic voting systems.

3. Anonymous International: A Russian activist group that leaks documents from the Kremlin, including some related to the Ukraine conflict.

The passage highlights how these groups use various hacking techniques to gather and disseminate information, disrupt operations, and influence public opinion. It also mentions the denial of official use of hacked information by Ukrainian military spokesman Oleksiy Dmytrashkivsky.

summary: A diverse group of hackers, including the Ukrainian Cyber Troops, Cyber Berkut, and Anonymous International, are actively involved in the ongoing conflict between Ukraine and Russia. These groups engage in various cyber activities, such as releasing official documents, hijacking electronic systems, and conducting DDoS attacks. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, have targeted Russian servers and email accounts, while Cyber Berkut, an anti-Western group, has disrupted Ukrainian government websites and claimed to possess sensitive information. Anonymous International, a Russian activist group, has published leaked Kremlin documents and focuses on domestic Russian affairs, with some coverage of Ukraine. The Ukrainian military denies using hacker-obtained data for artillery fire, while media reports suggest otherwise. The activities of these groups significantly impact the conflict, revealing sensitive information and potentially influencing public opinion.

summary:
Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, are a group of hackers who claim to be independent activists. They have hacked into various Russian government and rebel websites, servers, and electronic payment systems, making public official documents and disrupting separatist funding. They use distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks and have also hacked into public CCTV systems to monitor troop movements. Other groups, such as Cyber Berkut and Anonymous International, also operate in the conflict, with differing goals and methods. Cyber Berkut is anti-Western and has hacked into Ukrainian government websites and electronic billboards to spread propaganda, while Anonymous International has leaked documents from the Kremlin, including emails from a key rebel commander.

On the other side of the conflict is Cyber Berkut, a staunchly anti-Western group which takes its name from the riot police used against protesters during the unrest in Kiev that led to the ousting of President Viktor Yanukovych. The group's declared goal is thwarting Ukraine's military plans and thus stopping the "genocide" that it accuses Kiev of unleashing at America's behest. Its motto is "We won't forgive or forget", and its rhetoric closely resembles that of Russian state media. During US Vice-President Joe Biden's visit to Kiev on 20-21 November, Cyber Berkut hacked several Ukrainian government websites, placing a message on their front pages which read: "Joseph Biden is the fascists' master." Cyber Berkut claims to have retrieved confidential documents from a mobile device used by one member of Mr Biden's team while it was in Kiev. The documents appear to detail Washington's military assistance to Ukraine. Another stunt carried out by Cyber Berkut is the apparent hacking of electronic billboards in Kiev, which were made to show a video branding Ukrainian officials and activists "war criminals" and featuring highly graphic images of civilians killed in the current conflict. They also claim to have disrupted the electronic vote-counting systems ahead of October's parliamentary election in Ukraine, to have leaked Ukrainian defence ministry data on losses and desertions, and to have blocked President Petro Poroshenko's website. In addition, Russian tabloid Komsomolskaya Pravda quoted a Facebook conversation allegedly hacked by Cyber Berkut, in which Ukrainian officials appear to admit that their forces downed Malaysia Airlines flight MH17. The claim went largely ignored elsewhere and has never been verified. Russian activist group Anonymous International made its name by publishing leaked documents from the Kremlin. It is otherwise known as b0ltai or Shaltay Boltay, which translates as "Humpty Dumpty". What is not clear is whether it obtains material through hacking or are given it by Kremlin insiders. The group focuses on Russia's domestic affairs, but some of its material covers Ukraine. In  November it published a letter from a Russian fighter in eastern Ukraine suggesting that locals did not support the separatist forces. And in May it made headlines leaking what it said were emails to and from former Russian FSB colonel Igor Girkin, also known as Strelkov, who was then a key rebel commander in eastern Ukraine. Access to Anonymous International's website is currently blocked in Russia. BBC Monitoring reports and analyses news from TV, radio, web and print media around the world. For more reports from BBC Monitoring, click here. You can follow BBC Monitoring on Twitter and Facebook.
summary:
Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

* Three prominent groups of hackers are involved in the conflict in Ukraine: the Ukrainian Cyber Troops, Cyber Berkut, and Anonymous International.
* The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, have hacked into Russian interior ministry servers, email accounts, and CCTV cameras, and have used distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks to disrupt rebel websites and funding.
* Cyber Berkut, an anti-Western group, has hacked into Ukrainian government websites, electronic billboards, and mobile devices, and has leaked confidential documents and disrupted electronic vote-counting systems.
* Anonymous International, a Russian activist group, has published leaked documents from the Kremlin and has focused on Russia's domestic affairs, but has also published material related to Ukraine.
* The hackers' activities have included monitoring troop movements, disrupting funding, and leaking confidential documents, and have had significant impacts on the conflict.
* Officials have denied using information obtained by hackers to direct artillery fire, but some media reports suggest otherwise.

summary: The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, Cyber Berkut, and Anonymous International are three groups of hackers who have been active in the conflict in Ukraine. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, have used DDoS attacks to disrupt rebel websites and have hacked into CCTV systems and network printers to spread pro-Ukrainian messages. Cyber Berkut, a pro-Russian group, has hacked into Ukrainian government websites and electronic billboards to spread anti-Ukrainian propaganda. Anonymous International, a Russian activist group, has published leaked documents from the Kremlin, including emails from a former Russian FSB colonel.

summary: The passage describes the activities of three groups of hackers involved in the conflict between Ukraine and Russia. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, hack into Russian servers and monitor rebel-held areas. They use distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks and target rebel accounts in electronic payment systems. Cyber Berkut, an anti-Western group, hacks Ukrainian government websites and carries out other disruptive actions. Anonymous International, also known as b0ltai or Shaltay Boltay, publishes leaked documents from the Kremlin and focuses on Russia's domestic affairs.

summary: The passage discusses the activities of various hacking groups involved in the Ukraine conflict. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, are known for hacking Russian servers and using DDoS attacks against rebel websites. They also disrupt separatist funding and monitor troop movements via hacked CCTV systems. Cyber Berkut, an anti-Western group, aims to thwart Ukraine's military plans and has hacked Ukrainian government websites and electronic billboards. They claim to have obtained confidential documents and disrupted electronic vote-counting systems. Anonymous International, also known as b0ltai, leaks documents from the Kremlin and focuses on Russia's domestic affairs, with some material related to Ukraine. The passage highlights the significant impact of these groups on the ongoing conflict.
